open_data_statements: 1 supplementary data 1).;     overall 384 variants were tested in the replication datasets (supplementary data 2).;     our analysis also strengthened the evidence of association with ad for three additional genomic loci including an association with a variant in plcg2 (rs3935877 maf = 0.13 or = 0.92 [0.90–0.95] p = 6.9 × 10?9 fig. 2d) and con?rmed another common variant in plcg2 a stop gain mutation in il-34 and a variant near hs3st1 (table 1 supplementary fig. 3 and supplementary data 2 3).;     3 supplementary data 4) we constructed a weighted prs based on the 39 genetic variants (excluding apoe genotypes) that showed gws evidence of association with ad (see methods fig. 4 and supplementary data 5).;     the prs was associated with a 1.27-fold (95% ci [1.23–1.32]) increased risk for every standard deviation increase in the prs (p = 7.3 × 10?39) and with a gradual risk increase when we strati?ed the dataset into 2% percentiles of the prs (fig. 5a supplementary data 6).;     the prs percentiles were associated with ad within the apoe genotype groups (fig. 5b supplementary data 7).;     finally we compared the risk extremes and found a 16.2-fold (95% ci [8.84–29.5] p = 1.5 × 10?19) increased risk for the highest-prs group (apoe ?4?4) compared with the lowest-prs group (apoe ?2?2/?2?3; supplementary data 8).;     the cox regression also showed an impact of apoe on aao mainly on apoe ?4?4 (signi?cant apoe-prs interaction (p = 0.021) fig. 5d supplementary data 9).;     abbreviations and more information about the genes can be found in supplementary data 4.;     for further details on the contribution of the sites see supplementary data 10.;     (supplementary data 11 supplementary fig.;     after study-speci?c variant ?ltering and quality-control procedures we performed a ?xed effects inverse-variance–weighted metaanalysis22 on the discovery and follow-up stages (supplementary data 1 and supplementary data 12).;     conditional analyses were performed in regions where multiple variants were associated with ad using logistic regression models adjusting for the genetic variants in the region (supplementary data 13 14).;     we calculated a weighted individual prs based on the 39 genetic variants that showed gws evidence of association with ad in the present study excluding apoe to check the impact of prs modulating apoe risk (table 1 and supplementary data 3).;     we weighted this by the effect size from previous igap studies [kunkle et al.42 (36 variants) sims et al.7 (2 variants) jun et al.43 (mapt locus) supplementary data 5].;     we used functional mapping and annotation of genomewide association studies23 (fuma v1.3.4c) to interpret snp-trait associations (see supplementary methods and supplementary data 15–18).
comment_3_repository: this is rather the opposite of a repository - just a link to a sharepoint cloud deposit, no way of finding it independently of the article at all
comment_10_assessment: seems to be a private link; the sharepoint is not sufficient and secure place to share the data with the third person

open_data_statements: for working concentrations of 600 nm mocetinostat and 7 nm panobinostat respectively stock solutions were further diluted in complete growth medium and added to cells in culture for 48 h.  generated for this study are available on ena under the accession code prjeb39208.;     the chip-seq data of h3k27ac in sicontrol and sisall4-treated m010817 cells generated for this study are available on ena under accession code prjeb39209.;     the cut&run seq data of sall4 and hdac2 in m010817 cells generated for this study are available on arrayexpress under accession code e-mtab-10163.;     data availability the rna seq datasets of hyperplastic and wild-type melanocytes from varum et al. 2019 are available on the european nucleotide archive (ena) under accession code prjeb30285.   when comparing hyperplastic to wild-type melanocytes by rna sequencing (rna seq) (supplementary data 1) we found among the top 20 upregulated genes one transcription factor sall4 (logfc 9.59 p value < 0.0001) 2  (fig. 1b).;     the complete list of all differentially expressed genes can be found under supplementary data 1. c immunohistochemical staining of wild-type melanocytes in murine hair follicles (left panel) and melanoma-prone melanocytes in hyperplastic tyr::nrasq61k; cdkn2a?/? mouse skin (right panel).;     to determine the molecular mechanism by which sall4 loss leads to increased invasion we performed rna seq on sicontrol and sisall4-treated m010817 cells and found 1004 genes signi?cantly upregulated and 1140 genes signi?cantly downregulated in sisall4 over sicontrol samples (fig. 4a; supplementary data 2).;     gene ontology (go) analysis with metacore™ revealed that the upregulated genes were strongly enriched in process networks related to cell adhesion/cytoskeleton developmental processes related to epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition angiogenesis and others (fig. 4b; supplementary data 2).;     oppositely the downregulated genes were enriched in process networks related to cell cycle regulation in?ammation and developmental processes such as hedgehog signaling or melanocyte differentiation (fig. 4c; supplementary data 2).;     of note  we chose to perform cut&run with two different antibodies per factor each set consisting of one antibody that had previously been published for cut&run or chip sequencing plus one additional one (supplementary data 3).;     to determine target genes of both sall4 and hdac2 we performed peak calling with seacr for loci that contained signi?cant peaks with at least 3 of the 4 antibodies used (fig. 5b c d; supplementary data 4).;     as we hypothesized that sall4 recruits hdac2 to speci?c loci to repress gene activity we assessed which sall4hdac2 targets (peaks with at least 3 of 4 sall4-hdac2 antibodies) were signi?cantly upregulated after sall4 knockdown  nature communications | (2021)12:5056 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-25326-8 | www.nature.com/naturecommunications  5   article  nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-25326-8  a  sictrl sis4  1.0 0.5 0  1.0 0.5 0  cell index  0.2  sictrl#2 sis4#2  0.6 0.3 0.0  g  20 30 time (hrs)  10  40  20 30 time (hrs)  40  h  m150548  0.1 tumor volume cm3  m010817 sic#1 sis#1 sic#2 sis#2  sictrl sisall4  0.05  sic#1 sis#1 sic#2 sis#2  2 1 0  4 3 2 1 0  (rna seq) and found 184 direct sall4-hdac2 targets with increased expression upon sall4 kd (fig. 6a; supplementary data 4).;     we next analyzed the sall4-hdac2 target genes that were downregulated upon sall4 loss (supplementary fig. 15a; supplementary data 4).;     to address this we reanalyzed the sall4-hdac2 peaks within melanocyte differentiation genes (supplementary data 5) using ciiider to predict transcription factors (tfs) signi?cantly enriched at these peaks (supplementary data 5).;     the resulting list of tfs (supplementary data 5) putatively bound to the same loci as sall4 and hdac2 was ?ltered for high stringency and further analyzed with string to predict protein–protein interactions with sall4 (supplementary fig. 15c red cluster).;     we also elaborated on genes that might putatively be regulated exclusively by either sall4 or hdac2 by screening for proteincoding genes that only show cut&run peaks with the two sall4 antibodies the two hdac2 antibodies respectively but no 3 of 4 shared peaks (supplementary data 6).;     by doing so we  found that genes exclusively bound by sall4 enrich in biological processes related to neurogenesis neurophysiological processes and others while genes exclusively bound by hdac2 enriched in various different process classes such as immune cell adhesion cell cycle apoptosis and developmental processes (supplementary data 6).;     to address this hypothesis we performed an h3k27ac chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (chip-seq) experiment of cells treated with sictrl or sisall4 (supplementary  data 7) to identify genes with differential histone acetylation upon sall4 knockdown (fig. 7a supplementary data 8).;     moreover when we correlated the loci bound by sall4-hdac2 and showing increased h3k27ac chip-seq peaks in sisall4 (fig. 7h) with increased rna expression after sall4 knockdown (fig. 4b supplementary data 2) we again found among others invasiveness genes such as tgfbr2 itga6 or vegfr-1 (supplementary data 9) that were enriched in biological processes related to cell adhesion tgf? signaling and others (supplementary data 9).;     we found signi?cantly gained h3k27ac peaks in 2566 genes and signi?cantly lost h3k27ac peaks in 1131 genes (supplementary data 8).;     within the more than 2000 genes with gained h3k27ac marks 261 genes also showed increased mrna levels (fig. 7i supplementary data 8) while within the more than 1000 genes with lost h3k27ac levels 137 genes showed decreased mrna expression (supplementary fig. 17a supplementary 10  data 8).;     indeed in our experiments binding of sall4 and hdac2 to pten (but not sall1) was con?rmed by cut&run (supplementary data 3 and 4).;     supplementary data 1 contains the complete list of differentially expressed genes in hyperplastic melanocytes compared to wild-type ones (with cutoffs for log2 ratio ? 0.58 or ??0.58 p value < 0.05 and fdr < 0.05) of which the top 20 genes are presented in fig. 1b.;     supplementary data 2 contains the complete list of differentially expressed genes (with cutoffs for log2 ratio ? 0.27 or ??0.27 p value < 0.05 and fdr < 0.05) used for the row z-score heatmap and the metacoretm analysis (also included in supplementary data 2) in fig. 4 a b.;     supplementary data 7 contains the list of signi?cant peaks in both the sictrl and sisall4 samples and supplementary data 8 contains the signi?cantly gained and lost h3k27ac regions of sisall4 over sictrl.   data availability the rna seq datasets of hyperplastic and wild-type melanocytes from varum et al. 2019 are available on the european nucleotide archive (ena) under accession code prjeb30285

supplementary data 4).;     we next analyzed the sall4-hdac2 target genes that were downregulated upon sall4 loss (supplementary fig. 15a; supplementary data 4).;     to address this we reanalyzed the sall4-hdac2 peaks within melanocyte differentiation genes (supplementary data 5) using ciiider to predict transcription factors (tfs) signi?cantly enriched at these peaks (supplementary data 5).;     the resulting list of tfs (supplementary data 5) putatively bound to the same loci as sall4 and hdac2 was ?ltered for high stringency and further analyzed with string to predict protein–protein interactions with sall4 (supplementary fig. 15c red cluster).;     we also elaborated on genes that might putatively be regulated exclusively by either sall4 or hdac2 by screening for proteincoding genes that only show cut&run peaks with the two sall4 antibodies the two hdac2 antibodies respectively but no 3 of 4 shared peaks (supplementary data 6).;     by doing so we  found that genes exclusively bound by sall4 enrich in biological processes related to neurogenesis neurophysiological processes and others while genes exclusively bound by hdac2 enriched in various different process classes such as immune cell adhesion cell cycle apoptosis and developmental processes (supplementary data 6).;     to address this hypothesis we performed an h3k27ac chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (chip-seq) experiment of cells treated with sictrl or sisall4 (supplementary  data 7) to identify genes with differential histone acetylation upon sall4 knockdown (fig. 7a supplementary data 8).;     moreover when we correlated the loci bound by sall4-hdac2 and showing increased h3k27ac chip-seq peaks in sisall4 (fig. 7h) with increased rna expression after sall4 knockdown (fig. 4b supplementary data 2) we again found among others invasiveness genes such as tgfbr2 itga6 or vegfr-1 (supplementary data 9) that were enriched in biological processes related to cell adhesion tgf? signaling and others (supplementary data 9).;     we found signi?cantly gained h3k27ac peaks in 2566 genes and signi?cantly lost h3k27ac peaks in 1131 genes (supplementary data 8).;     within the more than 2000 genes with gained h3k27ac marks 261 genes also showed increased mrna levels (fig. 7i supplementary data 8) while within the more than 1000 genes with lost h3k27ac levels 137 genes showed decreased mrna expression (supplementary fig. 17a supplementary 10  data 8).;     indeed in our experiments binding of sall4 and hdac2 to pten (but not sall1) was con?rmed by cut&run (supplementary data 3 and 4).;     supplementary data 1 contains the complete list of differentially expressed genes in hyperplastic melanocytes compared to wild-type ones (with cutoffs for log2 ratio ? 0.58 or ??0.58 p value < 0.05 and fdr < 0.05) of which the top 20 genes are presented in fig. 1b.;     supplementary data 2 contains the complete list of differentially expressed genes (with cutoffs for log2 ratio ? 0.27 or ??0.27 p value < 0.05 and fdr < 0.05) used for the row z-score heatmap and the metacoretm analysis (also included in supplementary data 2) in fig. 4 a b.;     supplementary data 7 contains the list of signi?cant peaks in both the sictrl and sisall4 samples and supplementary data 8 contains the signi?cantly gained and lost h3k27ac regions of sisall4 over sictrl.   data availability the rna seq datasets of hyperplastic and wild-type melanocytes from varum et al. 2019 are available on the european nucleotide archive (ena) under accession code prjeb30285

open_data_category: field-specific repository, supplement, data availability statement
open_data_statements: data availability the whole-exome sequencing data egad00001006400 and snp microarray data egad00010001978 generated in this study have been deposited in the european genome-phenome archive (ega) under study accession egas00001004659.   sixty-eight cases were assembled on a tissue microarray to uniformly perform immunohistochemical staining for selected markers (supplementary fig. 1a and supplementary data 1).;     since 35% of myc-bap positive cases (8/23) were negative for mycfp about one third of cases translocated myc to a non-igh partner (supplementary data 1).;     after variant discovery and ?ltering (for details see methods) we called somatic mutations with an average of 3.48 variants per mb and sample placing pbl among other cancer entities with moderate to high tumor mutational burden (tmb) (supplementary data 2 and supplementary fig.;     this analysis revealed 15 ccgs (q < 0.1 cohort frequency ?5%; fig. 1a supplementary fig. 6 and supplementary data 3 4).;     mutations of kras and hras occurred in 11% and 2% of cases respectively (fig. 1a and supplementary data 4).;     notably stat3 mutations occurred in only 10% (3/31) of hiv negative patients but in 47% (7/15) of hiv infected individuals (p = 0.003 q = 0.043 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5) suggesting a pathogenetic role of stat3 mutations especially in hiv-associated pbl.;     in 26% (22/85) of samples mutations affecting genes encoding for components of the notch signaling pathway were detectable including mutations in spen (8%) notch1 (7%) notch4 (6%) dtx1 (3%) notch2 (1%) and notch3 (1%) indicating a role of notch signaling in the molecular pathogenesis of pbl (supplementary data 4 and fig. 1d).;     1 landscape of somatic mutations in pbl determined by wes. a all called non-synonymous mutations in signi?cant genes according to mutsig2cv v3.11 (qm2cv < 0.1 cohort frequency _x0001_5%) are color-coded and shown for each pbl sample per column ranked by cohort frequency (see supplementary data 3 and 4 for all results).;     tp53 mutations occurred in 6% of ebv positive lymphoma cases (3/ 47) while ebv negative pbls harbored tp53 mutations in 24% (9/38) (p = 0.011 q = 0.193 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5).;     the genes encoding the methyltransferases kmt2a and kmt2d exhibited mutations in 8% and 6% respectively (supplementary data 4).;     of note 27% (7/26) of myc translocated cases were concomitantly mutated while untranslocated cases did not display a mutation (0/32) (p = 0.001 q = 0.017 wilcoxon test supplementary data 5 and fig. 1d) suggesting that myc mutations originate from somatic hypermutation14.;     however comparing top-mutated genes (frequency ?10%) and adjusting for multiple hypothesis testing muc4 was the only gene being signi?cantly more frequently mutated in the cohort of pbl samples without matched normal (p = 0.0004 q = 0.0194 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5).;     a total of nine mutations (three mutations with af 10–16% and six mutations with a higher af) were additionally revealed by targeted resequencing suggesting that the mutational cohort frequencies might be slightly underestimated due to a lower effective coverage for single genomic sites using wes (supplementary data 6).;     using the oncoscan platform we next analyzed 82 pbl samples for copy number alterations and identi?ed scnas using gistic v2.0.2315 (fig. 2 and supplementary data 7 8).;     for 49 pbl patients we were able to obtain corresponding clinical data (supplementary data 1).;     next we investigated whether selected genetic alterations and/ or clinical parameters (supplementary data 9) in?uence the prognosis of affected patients.;     see supplementary data 7 and 8 for all results.  mutated pbl showed a signi?cantly inferior outcome compared to patients with wild-type tp53 (p = 0.035 q = 0.140 log rank test; fig. 3d).;     indeed this analysis did not yield any additional genetic alterations or clinical parameters that in?uenced survival signi?cantly in the context of multiple hypothesis testing but con?rmed our ?ndings (supplementary data 9).;     we applied one-tailed wilcoxon rank-sum tests on available data for each selected genetic lesion (supplementary data 5).;     in our cohort we identi?ed 18 pbl cases with involvement of the oral cavity while in 36 patients the oral cavity was not affected (supplementary data 1).;     corresponding p values of two-sided log rank tests are shown for multiple hypothesis testing over preselected conditions see supplementary data 9. f hazard ratios by cox regression and corresponding pcox values describing the impact of signi?cant mutations scnas (with qm2cv/g2.0 < 0.1) or clinical metadata on lss for pbl patients treated with chop-like chemotherapy.;     6  nature communications | (2021)12:5183 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-25405-w | www.nature.com/naturecommunications   nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-25405-w  diseases organ transplantation or other viral infections such as chronic hepatitis c infection (supplementary data 1).;     pbl-1 has been derived from an hiv positive pbl patient and represents an adequate functional model showing the typical plasmablastic immunophenotype and characteristic genetic lesions21 (supplementary data 1 4 and 8).;     our screen revealed that shrnas directed against myc (2 out of 2) irf4 (4 out of 4) and stat3 (1 out of 1) were among the most signi?cantly depleted shrnas (fig. 4a and supplementary data 10).;     as described in 25% of primary pbl samples pbl-1 cells also harbor a missense mutation of stat3 within the sh2 domain (supplementary data 4) and pbl-1 represents an il-6 dependent cell line21.;     4 identi?cation of molecular targets for the treatment of pbl. a shrnas used in the shrna library screen performed in pbl-1 cells are sorted and ranked by the corresponding z-score of log2-transformed depletion ratios after 12 days (see supplementary data 10 for raw read counts). shrnas targeting irf4 myc and stat3 are highlighted. b the graphs show the percentage of viable shrna irf4 #1/#2-transduced cells over time normalized to control shrna and to day two fraction.;     from initially 118 collected cases 96 cases were histologically con?rmed as pbl according to the criteria of the who classi?cation of 20172 (supplementary fig. 1a and supplementary data 1).;     speci?cally the relative percentage of tumor blastic b-cells was recorded in increments of 10% taking into account the relative percentages of non-blastic bystander lymphocytes and histiocytes (supplementary data 1).;     sites of origin are listed in supplementary data 1.;     for 49 cases with molecular data corresponding clinical and survival data were retrieved (supplementary data 1).;     all other markers were scored to be positive or negative regardless of staining intensity according to a prede?ned cutoff (supplementary data 1).;     the 57 pbl specimens were hybridized with the vysis lsi myc dual color break-apart probe (bap) (abbot molecular wiesbaden germany) and 63 cases with the myc-igh fusion probe (fp) (abbot molecular) (supplementary data 1).;     for each sample we provided dna amounts as recommended by the ffpe qc kit (illumina) a qpcr-based method comparing the ability of ampli?cation for extracted dna to a reference template (supplementary data 1).;     all ?lter steps in the applied order are listed in supplementary data 2.;     based on variant statistics from mutect gatk and all annotations our ?lter hierarchy called 0.09% of all variants as somatic mutations (see supplementary data 2 for detailed mutation counts and percentages remaining after each ?ltering step).;     finally we considered all top genes with a mutsig2cv false discovery rate of q < 0.1 for subsequent analyses (supplementary data 3).;     targeted resequencing was performed by next generation sequencing (ion genestudio s5 prime thermo fisher scienti?c) using an ampliseq custom panel comprising hotspot regions in stat3 kras nras braf and the complete coding sequence of tp53 and tet2 (supplementary data 6).;     to test for a signi?cantly higher median mutation/scna count in one subcohort vs. the other we utilized a one-tailed wilcoxon rank-sum test for each selected genetic lesion (supplementary data 5).;     pbl cases without matched normal for all genes having a cohort frequency ?10% (supplementary data 5).;     fdrs were again computed using the bh method with a signi?cance threshold of q < 0.1 (supplementary data 9)83.;     as an additional independent exploratory analysis we tested for association between lss and all signi?cant mutations (qm2cv < 0.1) all signi?cant scnas (qg2.0 < 0.1) as well as clinical metadata using univariate cox proportional hazard regression fdrs were calculated according to bh (supplementary data 9)83.;     in brief a pool of 2669 shrnas (supplementary data 10) was subcloned into a retroviral vector system allowing doxycyclineinduced expression and was transduced into pbl-1 cells89.;     after batch normalization and pre-?ltering of shrna reads with low coverage (sum of read counts at day12 on/off dox <50 [301 shrnas]) we assessed the fold change and signi?cance of shrna depletion comparing the shrna representation in samples after 12 days with vs. without induced shrna using deseq291 (for raw read counts quality control details and results see supplementary data 10).   data availability the whole-exome sequencing data egad00001006400

    our screen revealed that shrnas directed against myc (2 out of 2) irf4 (4 out of 4) and stat3 (1 out of 1) were among the most signi?cantly depleted shrnas (fig. 4a and supplementary data 10).;     as described in 25% of primary pbl samples pbl-1 cells also harbor a missense mutation of stat3 within the sh2 domain (supplementary data 4) and pbl-1 represents an il-6 dependent cell line21.;     4 identi?cation of molecular targets for the treatment of pbl. a shrnas used in the shrna library screen performed in pbl-1 cells are sorted and ranked by the corresponding z-score of log2-transformed depletion ratios after 12 days (see supplementary data 10 for raw read counts). shrnas targeting irf4 myc and stat3 are highlighted. b the graphs show the percentage of viable shrna irf4 #1/#2-transduced cells over time normalized to control shrna and to day two fraction.;     from initially 118 collected cases 96 cases were histologically con?rmed as pbl according to the criteria of the who classi?cation of 20172 (supplementary fig. 1a and supplementary data 1).;     speci?cally the relative percentage of tumor blastic b-cells was recorded in increments of 10% taking into account the relative percentages of non-blastic bystander lymphocytes and histiocytes (supplementary data 1).;     sites of origin are listed in supplementary data 1.;     for 49 cases with molecular data corresponding clinical and survival data were retrieved (supplementary data 1).;     all other markers were scored to be positive or negative regardless of staining intensity according to a prede?ned cutoff (supplementary data 1).;     the 57 pbl specimens were hybridized with the vysis lsi myc dual color break-apart probe (bap) (abbot molecular wiesbaden germany) and 63 cases with the myc-igh fusion probe (fp) (abbot molecular) (supplementary data 1).;     for each sample we provided dna amounts as recommended by the ffpe qc kit (illumina) a qpcr-based method comparing the ability of ampli?cation for extracted dna to a reference template (supplementary data 1).;     all ?lter steps in the applied order are listed in supplementary data 2.;     based on variant statistics from mutect gatk and all annotations our ?lter hierarchy called 0.09% of all variants as somatic mutations (see supplementary data 2 for detailed mutation counts and percentages remaining after each ?ltering step).;     finally we considered all top genes with a mutsig2cv false discovery rate of q < 0.1 for subsequent analyses (supplementary data 3).;     targeted resequencing was performed by next generation sequencing (ion genestudio s5 prime thermo fisher scienti?c) using an ampliseq custom panel comprising hotspot regions in stat3 kras nras braf and the complete coding sequence of tp53 and tet2 (supplementary data 6).;     to test for a signi?cantly higher median mutation/scna count in one subcohort vs. the other we utilized a one-tailed wilcoxon rank-sum test for each selected genetic lesion (supplementary data 5).;     pbl cases without matched normal for all genes having a cohort frequency ?10% (supplementary data 5).;     fdrs were again computed using the bh method with a signi?cance threshold of q < 0.1 (supplementary data 9)83.;     as an additional independent exploratory analysis we tested for association between lss and all signi?cant mutations (qm2cv < 0.1) all signi?cant scnas (qg2.0 < 0.1) as well as clinical metadata using univariate cox proportional hazard regression fdrs were calculated according to bh (supplementary data 9)83.;     in brief a pool of 2669 shrnas (supplementary data 10) was subcloned into a retroviral vector system allowing doxycyclineinduced expression and was transduced into pbl-1 cells89.;     after batch normalization and pre-?ltering of shrna reads with low coverage (sum of read counts at day12 on/off dox <50 [301 shrnas]) we assessed the fold change and signi?cance of shrna depletion comparing the shrna representation in samples after 12 days with vs. without induced shrna using deseq291 (for raw read counts quality control details and results see supplementary data 10).   data availability the whole-exome sequencing data egad00001006400

open_data_category: field-specific repository, supplement, data availability statement
open_data_statements: data availability the whole-exome sequencing data egad00001006400 and snp microarray data egad00010001978 generated in this study have been deposited in the european genome-phenome archive (ega) under study accession egas00001004659.   sixty-eight cases were assembled on a tissue microarray to uniformly perform immunohistochemical staining for selected markers (supplementary fig. 1a and supplementary data 1).;     since 35% of myc-bap positive cases (8/23) were negative for mycfp about one third of cases translocated myc to a non-igh partner (supplementary data 1).;     after variant discovery and ?ltering (for details see methods) we called somatic mutations with an average of 3.48 variants per mb and sample placing pbl among other cancer entities with moderate to high tumor mutational burden (tmb) (supplementary data 2 and supplementary fig.;     this analysis revealed 15 ccgs (q < 0.1 cohort frequency ?5%; fig. 1a supplementary fig. 6 and supplementary data 3 4).;     mutations of kras and hras occurred in 11% and 2% of cases respectively (fig. 1a and supplementary data 4).;     notably stat3 mutations occurred in only 10% (3/31) of hiv negative patients but in 47% (7/15) of hiv infected individuals (p = 0.003 q = 0.043 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5) suggesting a pathogenetic role of stat3 mutations especially in hiv-associated pbl.;     in 26% (22/85) of samples mutations affecting genes encoding for components of the notch signaling pathway were detectable including mutations in spen (8%) notch1 (7%) notch4 (6%) dtx1 (3%) notch2 (1%) and notch3 (1%) indicating a role of notch signaling in the molecular pathogenesis of pbl (supplementary data 4 and fig. 1d).;     1 landscape of somatic mutations in pbl determined by wes. a all called non-synonymous mutations in signi?cant genes according to mutsig2cv v3.11 (qm2cv < 0.1 cohort frequency _x0001_5%) are color-coded and shown for each pbl sample per column ranked by cohort frequency (see supplementary data 3 and 4 for all results).;     tp53 mutations occurred in 6% of ebv positive lymphoma cases (3/ 47) while ebv negative pbls harbored tp53 mutations in 24% (9/38) (p = 0.011 q = 0.193 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5).;     the genes encoding the methyltransferases kmt2a and kmt2d exhibited mutations in 8% and 6% respectively (supplementary data 4).;     of note 27% (7/26) of myc translocated cases were concomitantly mutated while untranslocated cases did not display a mutation (0/32) (p = 0.001 q = 0.017 wilcoxon test supplementary data 5 and fig. 1d) suggesting that myc mutations originate from somatic hypermutation14.;     however comparing top-mutated genes (frequency ?10%) and adjusting for multiple hypothesis testing muc4 was the only gene being signi?cantly more frequently mutated in the cohort of pbl samples without matched normal (p = 0.0004 q = 0.0194 wilcoxon test; supplementary data 5).;     a total of nine mutations (three mutations with af 10–16% and six mutations with a higher af) were additionally revealed by targeted resequencing suggesting that the mutational cohort frequencies might be slightly underestimated due to a lower effective coverage for single genomic sites using wes (supplementary data 6).;     using the oncoscan platform we next analyzed 82 pbl samples for copy number alterations and identi?ed scnas using gistic v2.0.2315 (fig. 2 and supplementary data 7 8).;     for 49 pbl patients we were able to obtain corresponding clinical data (supplementary data 1).;     next we investigated whether selected genetic alterations and/ or clinical parameters (supplementary data 9) in?uence the prognosis of affected patients.;     see supplementary data 7 and 8 for all results.  mutated pbl showed a signi?cantly inferior outcome compared to patients with wild-type tp53 (p = 0.035 q = 0.140 log rank test; fig. 3d).;     indeed this analysis did not yield any additional genetic alterations or clinical parameters that in?uenced survival signi?cantly in the context of multiple hypothesis testing but con?rmed our ?ndings (supplementary data 9).;     we applied one-tailed wilcoxon rank-sum tests on available data for each selected genetic lesion (supplementary data 5).;     in our cohort we identi?ed 18 pbl cases with involvement of the oral cavity while in 36 patients the oral cavity was not affected (supplementary data 1).;     corresponding p values of two-sided log rank tests are shown for multiple hypothesis testing over preselected conditions see supplementary data 9. f hazard ratios by cox regression and corresponding pcox values describing the impact of signi?cant mutations scnas (with qm2cv/g2.0 < 0.1) or clinical metadata on lss for pbl patients treated with chop-like chemotherapy.;     pbl-1 has been derived from an hiv positive pbl patient and represents an adequate functional model showing the typical plasmablastic immunophenotype and characteristic genetic lesions21 (supplementary data 1 4 and 8).;     our screen revealed that shrnas directed against myc (2 out of 2) irf4 (4 out of 4) and stat3 (1 out of 1) were among the most signi?cantly depleted shrnas (fig. 4a and supplementary data 10).;     as described in 25% of primary pbl samples pbl-1 cells also harbor a missense mutation of stat3 within the sh2 domain (supplementary data 4) and pbl-1 represents an il-6 dependent cell line21.;     4 identi?cation of molecular targets for the treatment of pbl. a shrnas used in the shrna library screen performed in pbl-1 cells are sorted and ranked by the corresponding z-score of log2-transformed depletion ratios after 12 days (see supplementary data 10 for raw read counts). shrnas targeting irf4 myc and stat3 are highlighted. b the graphs show the percentage of viable shrna irf4 #1/#2-transduced cells over time normalized to control shrna and to day two fraction.;     from initially 118 collected cases 96 cases were histologically con?rmed as pbl according to the criteria of the who classi?cation of 20172 (supplementary fig. 1a and supplementary data 1).;     speci?cally the relative percentage of tumor blastic b-cells was recorded in increments of 10% taking into account the relative percentages of non-blastic bystander lymphocytes and histiocytes (supplementary data 1).;     sites of origin are listed in supplementary data 1.;     for 49 cases with molecular data corresponding clinical and survival data were retrieved (supplementary data 1).;     all other markers were scored to be positive or negative regardless of staining intensity according to a prede?ned cutoff (supplementary data 1).;     the 57 pbl specimens were hybridized with the vysis lsi myc dual color break-apart probe (bap) (abbot molecular wiesbaden germany) and 63 cases with the myc-igh fusion probe (fp) (abbot molecular) (supplementary data 1).;     for each sample we provided dna amounts as recommended by the ffpe qc kit (illumina) a qpcr-based method comparing the ability of ampli?cation for extracted dna to a reference template (supplementary data 1).;     all ?lter steps in the applied order are listed in supplementary data 2.;     based on variant statistics from mutect gatk and all annotations our ?lter hierarchy called 0.09% of all variants as somatic mutations (see supplementary data 2 for detailed mutation counts and percentages remaining after each ?ltering step).;     finally we considered all top genes with a mutsig2cv false discovery rate of q < 0.1 for subsequent analyses (supplementary data 3).;     targeted resequencing was performed by next generation sequencing (ion genestudio s5 prime thermo fisher scienti?c) using an ampliseq custom panel comprising hotspot regions in stat3 kras nras braf and the complete coding sequence of tp53 and tet2 (supplementary data 6).;     to test for a signi?cantly higher median mutation/scna count in one subcohort vs. the other we utilized a one-tailed wilcoxon rank-sum test for each selected genetic lesion (supplementary data 5).;     pbl cases without matched normal for all genes having a cohort frequency ?10% (supplementary data 5).;     fdrs were again computed using the bh method with a signi?cance threshold of q < 0.1 (supplementary data 9)83.;     as an additional independent exploratory analysis we tested for association between lss and all signi?cant mutations (qm2cv < 0.1) all signi?cant scnas (qg2.0 < 0.1) as well as clinical metadata using univariate cox proportional hazard regression fdrs were calculated according to bh (supplementary data 9)83.;     in brief a pool of 2669 shrnas (supplementary data 10) was subcloned into a retroviral vector system allowing doxycyclineinduced expression and was transduced into pbl-1 cells89.;     after batch normalization and pre-?ltering of shrna reads with low coverage (sum of read counts at day12 on/off dox <50 [301 shrnas]) we assessed the fold change and signi?cance of shrna depletion comparing the shrna representation in samples after 12 days with vs. without induced shrna using deseq291 (for raw read counts quality control details and results see supplementary data 10).   data availability the whole-exome sequencing data egad00001006400

open_data_statements: data availability the raw proteomics data have been deposited in the pride database under accession codes pxd018345 and pxd018346.   in addition to isg15 we identi?ed rnf213 as the most enriched protein in the isg15 vlps associated with high spectral and peptide counts (fig. 1b supplementary data 1).;     1 supplementary data 1).;     1 supplementary data 1).;     proteins identi?ed as isg15 interaction partners in all virotrap screens are annotated (n = 29) and listed in supplementary data 1. c vlps containing isg15 or edhfr were collected and analyzed by immunoblot (ib) against rnf213 isg15 and gag.;     for each protein the log2 (isg15/control) fold change value is indicated on the x-axis while the statistical signi?cance (?log p-value) is indicated on the y-axis (supplementary data 1).

their pooled characteristics are shown in table 1 and the individual study descriptions are provided in supplementary data 1 and 2.;     we investigated the association of kidney traits with dna methylation in blood at up to 441870 cpgs the overlap of cpgs covered by the illumina methylationepic beadchip and the illumina humanmethylation450 beadchip array which were used for measurement by all but one study (supplementary data 3).;     we observed no or little in?ation in study-speci?c ewas (egfr mean in?ation = 1.00 uacr mean in?ation = 1.00 supplementary data 1 and 2).;     1a supplementary data 4 see methods) including previously reported ones14.;     1b supplementary data 5 see methods).;     there was a low overlap between the replicated ewas and previously reported gwas loci for both egfr (noverlap = 10 out of 69; supplementary data 4) and uacr (noverlap = 1 out of 7; supplementary data 5).;     the detailed results from these meta-analyses for all suggestive associations are provided in supplementary data 6 (egfr) and 7 (uacr).;     2 supplementary data 4 and 5).;     2 supplementary data 4 and 5).;     four probes were located near a common snp (supplementary data 4; cg10960375-rs113564504; cg11544657-rs2083577; cg01817897-rs142643977; cg06930757-rs112223111) which however were not associated with any gwas trait according to the phenoscanner v2 resource (accessed 02/12/2021 pgwas < 5e?8 including proxy snps with eur r² > 0.8)23.;     of the 69 cpgs associated with egfr 53 were also associated with prevalent ckd in a meta-analysis of 25609 individuals including 2376 cases with a consistent effect direction (p-value < 0.05/69; supplementary data 4 supplementary fig.;     4 supplementary data 4 see methods).;     in the same cohort egfrassociated cpgs cg18194850 (p-value = 1.6e?5) and cg07242931 (p-value = 2.3e?5) were also associated with time to kidney 4  failure or acute kidney injury (supplementary data 8 see methods).;     3b supplementary data 5 supplementary fig.;     to obtain insights into possible functional mechanisms of the egfr- and uacr-associated cpgs we tested the correlation of their dna methylation levels with mrna levels of genes encoded in cis in whole blood as well as in blood monocytes (see methods supplementary data 9).;     all results of the gene expression analysis are provided in supplementary data 9.;     6a table 2 supplementary data 10).;     6c supplementary data 10).;     results for all primary and sensitivity mr analyses are shown in supplementary data 11 and 12 and supplementary fig.;     we performed transcription factor binding site histone mark and pathway enrichment analyses based on the 967 cpgs that showed suggestive association with egfr (pvalue < 1e?05; supplementary data 6) and the 270 cpgs that showed suggestive associations with uacr (p-value < 1e?5; supplementary data 7) in the meta-analysis to maximize statistical power of enrichment analyses (see methods) 14.;     4a supplementary data 13) including cebpb (p-value = 1.75e?06 cross-tissue track) and ep300 (p-value = 7.49e?09 cross-tissue track).;     4b supplementary data 14) with the strongest association for polr2a (p-value = 6.93e?19) fos (p-value = 1.28e?12) and ep300 (p-value = 1.20e?10).;     4c supplementary data 15) and 79 of 195 for uacr (fig.;     4d supplementary data 16).;     4d supplementary data 16).;     signi?cant enrichment was observed for 27 terms (25 go one kegg one reactome; supplementary data 17 fig.;     5a) for egfr and 91 terms (87 go four reactome; supplementary data 18 fig.;     additional pathways that were enriched included white blood cell migration as for the egfr results (supplementary data 18).;     twenty-one egfr sites were associated with blood pressure alcohol consumption bmi sex soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor 2 and/or smoking status and ?ve uacr sites were previously associated with alcohol consumption smoking status bmi educational attainment ?-glutamyl transferase soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor 2 type 2 diabetes mellitus and/or several serum metabolites (table 2 supplementary data 19).;     despite the inclusion of data from a substantial number of individuals of non-ea ancestry the overall results of the transethnic ewas might be driven by data from individuals of ea ancestry which represented 70% (egfr) / 65% (uacr) of our study (supplementary data 3 and 4).;     the results passing a benjamini-hochberg fdr < 0.05 are shown but are limited to the top 27 pathways for uacr.  cg07242931 in man1c1 and cg18194850 in suclg2 were not only associated with egfr but predicted time to kidney failure or acute kidney injury (supplementary data 8).;     5b supplementary data 18) the number of signi?cant correlations between uacrassociated cpgs and transcript levels is quite low.;     when interpreting the causal effect observed in our study it should however be kept in mind that the mr analyses for cpg cg04864179 showed signi?cant heterogeneity (p < 0.05) among the instruments (supplementary data 11 and supplementary fig.;     to maximize phenotype standardization across studies an analysis plan and a command line script (https://github.com/ genepi-freiburg/ckdgen-pheno/tree/ckdgen-ewas-pheno) were created and provided to all participating studies (predominantly population-based studies; supplementary data 1 and 2).;     dna methylation data preprocessing was performed according to individual study protocols including background correction quantile normalization probe ?ltering sample ?ltering snp matching to the snp control probe locations outlier ?ltering and assay type correction (supplementary data 3).;     studies were split into discovery and replication by chronological order of contribution to the ckdgen consortium meta-analysis (supplementary data 1 and 2).;     the cpgs that were associated with egfr and uacr respectively at p-value < 1e?05 in the meta-analysis were used as input (supplementary data 6 and 7) and 10000 resampling runs an active proximity ?lter and considered fdr < 0.05 as signi?cant (supplementary data 13 and 14).;     histone mark enrichment analyses were performed analogously (supplementary data 15 and 16).;     we considered a gene set or pathway to be signi?cantly enriched at fdr < 0.05 correcting for multiple testing within each database using the benjamini and hochberg method (supplementary data 17 and 18)77.  using the published dataset of kennedy et al.;     in the case of multiple ewas for similar traits only the one with the largest sample size was included in the lookup (supplementary data 19).
open_code_statements: code availability the script for generating the phenotypes used in the ewas is available via github [https://github.com/genepi-freiburg/ckdgen-pheno-ewas]84. to maximize phenotype standardization across studies an analysis plan and a command line script (https://github.com/ genepi-freiburg/ckdgen-pheno/tree/ckdgen-ewas-pheno) were created and provided to all participating studies (predominantly population-based studies; supplementary data 1 and 2).
comment_3_repository: the consortium website cannot be considered a repository, because all datasets are on one page, no individual landing pages; also little to no metadata

open_data_category: field-specific repository, supplement, data availability statement
open_data_statements: whole-genome sequences are available on the european nucleotide archive (ena) database under bioproject number prjeb31628 [https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/browser/view/ prjeb31628].;     data availability the sequence data that support the ?ndings of the study have been deposited in the european nucleotide archive (ena) database under bioproject number prjeb31628 [https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/browser/view/prjeb31628].   in addition we included sequences from 231 environmental isolates of l. pneumophila subsp. pneumophila from water sources such as cooling towers and plumbing systems sent to the reference laboratory for routine testing and surveillance (supplementary data 1).;     here we observed that lag-1 can be associated with different combinations of sg-1 lps genes and still express the expected 4  lag-1 phenotype represented by the mab 3/1-speci?c epitope (dresden mab scheme) (supplementary data 1)3637.;     this suggests that recombination is active on a genome-wide scale in agreement with earlier analyses of rates of recombination across the genome4546 (supplementary fig. 5 and supplementary data 2).;     the earliest isolates obtained from a nosocomial outbreak in 1984/198530 contained variant 3 (corby) of the lag-1 gene and all were found to express the mab 3/1 epitope (supplementary data 1).;     speci?cally a nonsense mutation (l48*) an insertion of a transposase and the acquisition of a deleterious substitution (h28l) (fig. 4b) each correlated with a lack of reactivity with mab 3/1 from the dresden panel classi?cation (supplementary data 1).;     accession numbers of each genome used is listed in supplementary data s1.   data availability the sequence data that support the ?ndings of the study have been deposited in the european nucleotide archive (ena) database under bioproject number prjeb31628
open_code_statements: the modi?ed subsampling script is available on github.com/bawee/treemmer.;     code availability we have implemented a modi?ed version of the subsampling software treemmer (https://github.com/fmenardo/treemmer)75 which is available at http://github.com/ bawee/treemmer.

open_data_statements: the scatac-seq data is available on terra and github (see below) and the scths-seq data is available on geo (gse154027).  the scatac-seq data is available on terra and github (see below) and the scths-seq data is available on geo (gse154027). to address this account for covariate interactions and ensure robustness we (1) used a simple noise model (poisson) to reduce overfitting of donor variability; (2) confirmed that effect directions of significant associations were consistent in a pseudo-bulk analysis (modeling only donor variation; methods and supplementary data 1–4); (3) confirmed summarized age sex and smoking associations with a model including interaction terms (methods and supplementary data 1–4); and (4) separated significant associations that passed all above confirmations into ‘robust trends’ and ‘indications’ depending on their robustness to holding out individual datasets (methods and supplementary data 1–4).;     7 supplementary data 5–8 and methods).;     to counteract this effect we verified that significant associations were consistent when modeling only donor variation via pseudo-bulk analysis (supplementary data 1–4).;     after filtering as described above model 2 was fit to the data (supplementary data 1–4).;     as metadata on smoking status were only available for a subset of the data we also fitted a reduced version of models 2 and 3 without the smoking covariate on a larger dataset to confirm sex and age associations (supplementary data 5–8).
open_code_statements: the scatac-seq data is available on terra and github (see below) and the scths-seq data is available on geo (gse154027).
comment_2_own_data: one of many authors also contributed to the shared dataset; we currently have no limitation of overlap, so this is sufficient to be counted as own data
comment_10_assessment: I think it is clearly open data by our definition, but we need to discuss with Vladi and Miriam, whether this is counted as a last authors from Charité and BIH - in last author position is a huge consortium, and I think there should not be OD-LOM for it

comment_1_licenses: dataset shared under an MIT license; as it is a software license, and not really suited for data, I consider it not shared under a standardized license, but we should make it explicit in the criteria
comment_9_analytical_replication: it is difficult to assess this data, but it is referred to in the article, and lacking the disciplinary knowledge, we have to assume raw data
comment_10_assessment: the data is provided as a basis for the figures in the article, as well as the scripts to perform the analysis

comment_5_data_access: data access is restricted; there are further datasets shared like this; if this were the only type of data available, we should not give LOM fior it, because (a) the way to access is quite intransparent (b) there is cost, and it is not immediately clear how high it is and whether justified (c) it is not clear without logging in, whether this is own data, or raw data; however, for our statistics, we can count is as a case of restricted data sharing, and in any case there was also open data shared

open_data_statements: the homology model was constructed by using the following structural templates of evolutionarily related class a gpcrs: (i) the leucine-rich repeat domain (lrrd) complexed with hormone was modeled based on the solved fshr lrrd - fsh complex structure (protein data bank (pdb) id: 4ay9)5253 this part of model included herring tshr cys33 - asn296 and fragments of the hinge region gln297 - thr312 and ser393 - ile421; (ii) the available structural complex of ?2-adrenoreceptor with gs-protein (pdb id: 3sn6)54 was used as the template to model the seven-transmembrane helix domain (7tmd) of herring tshr in the active conformation; (iii) the extracellular loop 2 (ecl2) was built by using the ecl2 of ?-opioid receptor (pdb id: 6dde)55.;     data availability the raw atac-seq reads have been deposited in the ncbi sequence read archive (sra) under bioproject accession no. prjna660525.;     the snp allele frequency data from han et al.16 used to perform the genome scan is available in dryad (https://doi.org/ 10.5061/dryad.pnvx0k6kr)57 and the corresponding sequence data is available in ncbi under the bioproject prjna642736. the snp allele frequency data from han et al.16 used to perform the genome scan is available in dryad (https://doi.org/ 10.5061/dryad.pnvx0k6kr)57 and the corresponding sequence data is available in ncbi under the bioproject prjna642736.;     the raw data to build fig. 1c has been uploaded to the github repository as a compressed directory https://github.com/leifanderssonlab/ chen_et_al_2021_tshr_functional/blob/main/data-pi-tajimasd-popoolation1.tar.gz doi: 10.5281/zenodo.473372858.;     code availability custom code and associated data ?les used for the genome analysis are available in the repository https://github.com/leifanderssonlab/chen_et_al_2021_tshr_functional https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.473372858. the raw data to build fig. 1c has been uploaded to the github repository as a compressed directory https://github.com/leifanderssonlab/ chen_et_al_2021_tshr_functional/blob/main/data-pi-tajimasd-popoolation1.tar.gz doi: 10.5281/zenodo.473372858.;     code availability custom code and associated data ?les used for the genome analysis are available in the repository https://github.com/leifanderssonlab/chen_et_al_2021_tshr_functional https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.473372858. all other raw data supporting the ?ndings of this study are provided in supplementary data 1.   data availability the raw atac-seq reads have been deposited in the ncbi sequence read archive (sra) under bioproject accession no. prjna660525

open_data_statements: data availability the validated hot and cold spots labels for each sign are publicly available for download on zenodo (https://doi. org/10.5281/zenodo.4425256 20 january 2021 date last accessed) and are accessible in lead-dbs (https://www. lead-dbs.org/ 20 july 2020 date last accessed).     data availability the validated hot and cold spots labels for each sign are publicly available for download on zenodo
open_code_statements: sign-specific structural connectivity as an additional exploratory analysis to investigate patterns of structural connectivity between sign-specific hot spots and motor regions-of-interest previously implicated with motor improvement61220 we seeded hott hotr hotb and hota in a large averaged diffusion template created from the diffusion-weighted imaging scans of 1065 human connectome project (http://www.humancon nectomeproject.org/ 15 june 2020 date last accessed) subjects.21 additional details on acquisition parameters  statistical analyses r (https://www.r-project.org/ 15 june 2020 date last accessed version 3.4.4) and rminc (https://github.com/ mouse-imaging-centre/rminc 20 july 2020 date last accessed) were used (supplementary material).
comment_10_assessment: there is no possibility to open this format, though it tends to be raw data: (1) each file is about 277Mb, and (2) the description doesn't idicate that it might be a selection of data or just illustrations for the article

open_data_statements: 8  data availability the gwas summary statistics and supporting information on low grip strength in older people are available on the musculoskeletal knowledge portal (www.mskkp.org) and the gwas catalogue (www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas accession numbers gcst90007526 gcst90007527 gcst90007528 gcst90007529 gcst90007530 and gcst90007531).   1 table 1; supplementary data 1).;     twelve of the ?fteen lead snps from the gwas have not previously been identi?ed in studies of grip strength analyzed on a continuous scale across all ages (supplementary data 2 & 3) and only 3 of the 64 loci associated with overall muscle strength11 are signi?cant in our analysis of low strength (supplementary data 4).;     this included the three most strongly associated variants near hla-dqa1 (previously implicated in rheumatoid arthritis: see supplementary data 2) gdf5 (‘growth differentiation factor 5’: previously implicated in height waist hip ratio muscle mass and osteoarthritis) and dym (‘dymeclin’: implicated in in height).;     overall two of the ?fteen identi?ed lead variants (or proxies) have not previously been implicated in anthropometric or musculoskeletal phenotypes in the gwas catalogue (see supplementary data 2).;     although the lead aldh1a2 snp itself has not been identi?ed in previous gwas other independent variants (r2 < 0.6) at the same locus (e.g. rs3204689) have been found to be associated with osteoarthritis (supplementary data 2).;     rows in bold are those not found in previously published gwas (see supplementary data 2 and 3).;     see supplementary data 1 for metal output and supplementary data 6 for gtex  the analysis of males only (total n = 118371 with 13327 cases 11.3%) identi?ed three genomic loci associated with the ewgsop low grip strength de?nition.;     see supplementary data 5.;     five loci were signi?cant in the analysis (p < 5 × 10?8) only  nature communications | (2021)12:654 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w | www.nature.com/naturecommunications  3   article  nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w  to investigate the possible phenotypes associated with the genes highlighted by metaxcan with many having clear effects on relevant phenotypes such as “growth” “lean mass” “body weight” “angiogenesis” “thymus involution” and “lipid metabolism” (supplementary data 9).;     see supplementary data 10 for details.;     we used data from the genotype-tissue expression project (gtex) v8 to identify whether the variants associated with low grip strength affect expression of genes (table 1; supplementary data 6).;     in magma analysis we found 80 go processes enriched in low grip strength-associated genes (see supplementary data 7 for details) mainly involved in the immune system and antigen presentation.;     using metaxcan17 we identi?ed 24 genes with expression in skeletal muscle signi?cantly enriched in the low grip strength gwas after benjamini-hochberg adjustment for multiple testing (supplementary data 8).;     3; supplementary data 11).;     we found signi?cantly increased likelihood of weakness (multiple testingadjusted p values < 0.05) with genetically predicted rheumatoid arthritis (odds ratio = 1.03 benjamini-hochberg adjusted p value = 5.3 × 10?4) presence of type-2 diabetes (or = 1.05 bh p = 2.5 × 10?3) or asthma and allergic disease (or = 1.07 bh p = 9.4 × 10-3) (supplementary data 11).;     the analysis of females only also identi?ed depression (or = 1.21 bh p = 2.75 × 10?2) and colorectal cancer (or = 1.06 bh p = 2.75 × 10?2) (supplementary data 12).;     full results of mendelian randomization available in supplementary data 11 12 and 13.;     in the males type-2 diabetes signi?cantly increased odds of ewgsop low grip (or = 1.08 bh p = 3.0 × 10?3) whereas greater plateletcrit (the volume occupied by platelets in the blood as a percentage) (or = 0.91 p = 3.0 × 10?3) and other haematological parameters appear to be protective (supplementary data 13).;     see supplementary data 14 for detailed results.;     as is noted in supplementary data 2 this gene is also associated with height in the gwas catalogue.;     in comparison to a previous study that analysed grip strength as a continuous measure in the uk biobank cohort9 that included  nature communications | (2021)12:654 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w | www.nature.com/naturecommunications   nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w  all aged (40–70 years) we found that only three of the 64 identi?ed variants were signi?cantly (p < 5 × 10?8) associated with ewgsop low grip strength (supplementary data 2).
comment_10_assessment: supplement in the article; reference in data avail section

open_data_statements: variants identified for et in this study and previously reported in spanish family are shown by red and black colors respectively placed below the image whereas those causing paramyotonia congenita of von eulenburg and normokalemic and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis are shown on the top of the structure. (d) alignment of stretches of the scn4a protein showing the conservation of mutated residues pro1560 gly1537 val1589 and met1592 (boxed regions) in several species of vertebrates. (e) three-dimensional structure of scn4a (green) and subunit Î²-1 (blue) complex (pdb-code 6agf).;     data avai lab ility s tatement the scn4a variant has been submitted in clinvar (sub10539254).
comment_10_assessment: generally decided for now not to consider ClinVar as a sufficient repository as it doesn't store any dataset, but only information; certain genetic variant submitted to clinvar registry, not document it as a reference

comment_10_assessment: https://github.com/khalednasr/nn-numerosity-zero is stated to contain data, but the result is a convolutional network, and I don't think that any data were generated, so I tend towards not open data; I cannot open the files in the repository, but it does not look like "satasets"

    after additionally removing the meqtls that were correlated with any of the ?ve gwas index snps at slc2a9 among ea persons (methods) cg13841979 was the only cpg with ?4 meqtls for mr analysis and showed nominally signi?cant causal effects on serum urate levels (p = 2.25e–2 supplementary data 10).;     across three datasets from populations of ea the heritability estimates of the replicated cpgs varied (supplementary data 9).;     chr chromosome mr mendelian randomization se standard error sd standard deviation. acpgs with signi?cant mediating effect for two urate gwas index snps (supplementary data 12 and 13). bcpgs associated with gene expression of slc2a9 in monocytes (supplementary data 14). ceffect size of cpgs on serum urate estimated in mg/dl per sd in rank-based transformed dna methylation beta levels.;     in sensitivity analysis the causal effect of cg03725404 for gout was supported by three mr methods robust to pleiotropy (supplementary data 11).;     two cpgs (cg11266682 and cg13841979) had signi?cant mediating effects (p < 0.0125) for two of the independent index snps (rs10017305 and rs6825187; supplementary data 12).;     from the meta-analysis of all three studies the mediating effects ranged from 21% by cg13841979 for rs10017305 (mediating effect: 0.05 mg/dl p = 4.7e–07) to 43% by cg11266682 for rs6825187 (mediating effect: 0.10 mg/dl p = 3.0e–5 supplementary data 13).;     of the 99 replicated cpgs 26 cpgs were signi?cantly associated with gene expression in cis in monocytes (p < 5e–4; supplementary data 14)27.;     4a and supplementary data 14).;     for gene expression in whole blood eight cpgs showed signi?cant associations (supplementary data 15).;     ankrd11 had lower expression in the kidney (log2 fold change: ?0.24 fdr = 5.6e–3; supplementary data 17).;     after correction for multiple testing signi?cant enrichment was observed for 55 terms (supplementary data 18).;     using published ewas summary statistics we investigated whether these relationships were also observed when studying epigenetic variation by examining the association between replicated urate-associated cpgs and other cardiometabolic traits (methods supplementary data 19).;     of the replicated urate-associated cpgs 17 had signi?cant associations with at least one cardiometabolic trait (fig. 8 and supplementary data 20).;     in addition 4 of the 17 cpgs that were associated with serum urate and cardiometabolic traits (cg16246545 at phgdh cg19693031 at nbpf20/ txnip cg06690548 at slc7a11 and cg06690548 at cpt1a) were associated with mostly lipid-related metabolites quanti?ed using nuclear magnetic resonance (supplementary data 21)39.;     dna methylation data preprocessing was performed according to individual study protocols which included background correction quantile normalization probe ?ltering sample ?ltering snp matching to the snp control probe locations outlier ?ltering and assay type correction (supplementary data 2).;     among the 24 contributing cohorts 14 cohorts excluded participants who were on urate-lowering medications whereas the other cohorts did not have this information available (supplementary data 1).;     studies were separated into discovery and replication cohorts by chronological order of contribution to this project (supplementary data 1).;     the sources of the gwas summary statistics of the potential confounders are reported in supplementary data 22.; open_data_statements: the full protocol is available on open science framework (osf) at https://osf.io/ 94w7u/?;     all syntax is available on osf at https://osf.io/94w7u/?;     the second cutoff score was derived from the combination of several parental burnout indicators based on a preregistered multi-method and multi-informant analysis strategy (i.e. selfreported measures [provided by participants] clinical judgments [completed by external judges based on a 5-min speech provided by participants on their parenting experience] and a biological measure of stress [the analysis of cortisol levels contained in participants’ hair]): parents were judged to have parental burnout if their score was equal to or greater 86 (see https://osf.io/ujfb3 for more details about the analysis strategy).;     data availability the full protocol database and syntaxes are available on osf https://osf.io/94w7u/?     data availability the full protocol database and syntaxes are available on osf
comment_10_assessment: the link is not sufficient, looks like a private link; so it is not findable in the repository; also the authorship is completely anonymous; only from the article text I might conclude that it is their own data

open_data_statements: 8  data availability the gwas summary statistics and supporting information on low grip strength in older people are available on the musculoskeletal knowledge portal (www.mskkp.org) and the gwas catalogue (www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas accession numbers gcst90007526 gcst90007527 gcst90007528 gcst90007529 gcst90007530 and gcst90007531).   1 table 1; supplementary data 1).;     twelve of the ?fteen lead snps from the gwas have not previously been identi?ed in studies of grip strength analyzed on a continuous scale across all ages (supplementary data 2 & 3) and only 3 of the 64 loci associated with overall muscle strength11 are signi?cant in our analysis of low strength (supplementary data 4).;     this included the three most strongly associated variants near hla-dqa1 (previously implicated in rheumatoid arthritis: see supplementary data 2) gdf5 (‘growth differentiation factor 5’: previously implicated in height waist hip ratio muscle mass and osteoarthritis) and dym (‘dymeclin’: implicated in in height).;     overall two of the ?fteen identi?ed lead variants (or proxies) have not previously been implicated in anthropometric or musculoskeletal phenotypes in the gwas catalogue (see supplementary data 2).;     although the lead aldh1a2 snp itself has not been identi?ed in previous gwas other independent variants (r2 < 0.6) at the same locus (e.g. rs3204689) have been found to be associated with osteoarthritis (supplementary data 2).;     rows in bold are those not found in previously published gwas (see supplementary data 2 and 3).;     see supplementary data 1 for metal output and supplementary data 6 for gtex  the analysis of males only (total n = 118371 with 13327 cases 11.3%) identi?ed three genomic loci associated with the ewgsop low grip strength de?nition.;     see supplementary data 5.;     five loci were signi?cant in the analysis (p < 5 × 10?8) only  nature communications | (2021)12:654 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w | www.nature.com/naturecommunications  3   article  nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w  to investigate the possible phenotypes associated with the genes highlighted by metaxcan with many having clear effects on relevant phenotypes such as “growth” “lean mass” “body weight” “angiogenesis” “thymus involution” and “lipid metabolism” (supplementary data 9).;     see supplementary data 10 for details.;     we used data from the genotype-tissue expression project (gtex) v8 to identify whether the variants associated with low grip strength affect expression of genes (table 1; supplementary data 6).;     in magma analysis we found 80 go processes enriched in low grip strength-associated genes (see supplementary data 7 for details) mainly involved in the immune system and antigen presentation.;     using metaxcan17 we identi?ed 24 genes with expression in skeletal muscle signi?cantly enriched in the low grip strength gwas after benjamini-hochberg adjustment for multiple testing (supplementary data 8).;     3; supplementary data 11).;     we found signi?cantly increased likelihood of weakness (multiple testingadjusted p values < 0.05) with genetically predicted rheumatoid arthritis (odds ratio = 1.03 benjamini-hochberg adjusted p value = 5.3 × 10?4) presence of type-2 diabetes (or = 1.05 bh p = 2.5 × 10?3) or asthma and allergic disease (or = 1.07 bh p = 9.4 × 10-3) (supplementary data 11).;     the analysis of females only also identi?ed depression (or = 1.21 bh p = 2.75 × 10?2) and colorectal cancer (or = 1.06 bh p = 2.75 × 10?2) (supplementary data 12).;     full results of mendelian randomization available in supplementary data 11 12 and 13.;     in the males type-2 diabetes signi?cantly increased odds of ewgsop low grip (or = 1.08 bh p = 3.0 × 10?3) whereas greater plateletcrit (the volume occupied by platelets in the blood as a percentage) (or = 0.91 p = 3.0 × 10?3) and other haematological parameters appear to be protective (supplementary data 13).;     see supplementary data 14 for detailed results.;     as is noted in supplementary data 2 this gene is also associated with height in the gwas catalogue.;     in comparison to a previous study that analysed grip strength as a continuous measure in the uk biobank cohort9 that included  nature communications | (2021)12:654 | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w | www.nature.com/naturecommunications   nature communications | https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-20918-w  all aged (40–70 years) we found that only three of the 64 identi?ed variants were signi?cantly (p < 5 × 10?8) associated with ewgsop low grip strength (supplementary data 2).
comment_10_assessment: the data in GWAS Catalog is of specific content, i.e. it is not a raw data as we used to it, but summery statistics; for this repository it is the raw data, so we decided to count it for LOM as such.

open_data_statements: based on prior studies it is controversial whether enhanced atherosclerosis among individuals with ma is likely to explain the migraine association with stroke34 suggesting the existence of alternative mechanisms including endothelial activation56 or a potential role of hypercoagulability and microemboli.5 however ?ndings on migraine and procoagulatory states are not consistent.7-12 in this study we investigated potential causal relationships between hemostatic pro?les and migraine by leveraging largescale genome-wide association study (gwas) summary statistics for migraine and migraine subtypes (ma and migraine without aura [mo])13 and for 8 hemostatic factors (including plasma levels or activities of ?brinogen14 d-dimer15 coagulation factor vii [fvii]16 coagulation factor viii [fviii]17 coagulation factor xi [fxi]18 von willebrand factor [vwf]17 tissue plasminogen activator [tpa]19 and plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 [pai-1]20 among up to 120246 individuals) 2 hemostasis clinical tests (activated partial thromboplastin time [aptt]21 and prothrombin time/international normalized ratio [pt/inr]21 which are commonly used to screen for coagulation-factor de?ciencies) as well as serum concentrations of 2 forms of ?brinopeptide a (?brinopeptide a [adsgegdfxaegggvr*] and phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a [adpsgegdfxaegggvr*]).22  methods gwas summary data for migraine and hemostatic profiles the latest gwas summary-level data for migraine (included 59674 cases and 316078 controls) and its subtypes ma (included 4837 cases and 49174 controls) and mo (included 4833 cases and 106834 controls) were obtained from the international headache genetics consortium which comprised 22 cohorts13 (appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10. 5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     to do this we ?rst extracted independent genome-wide signi?cant snps for each trait using a clumping function in plink25 (pngu.mgh.harvard.edu/purcell/plink/) resulting in sets of independent snps with p value ?5 × 10?8 and r2 < 0.05 in a 1000-kb window size (appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10.5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     neurology.org/n  results mendelian randomization we observed evidence of signi?cant e?ects of genetically determined increased fviii activity (odds ratio [95% con?dence interval] 1.05 [1.03 1.08]/sd of fviii p = 6.08 × 10?05) vwf level (1.05 [1.03 1.08]/sd of vwf p = 2.25 × 10?06) and phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a level (1.13 [1.07 1.19]/sd of phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a p = 5.44 × 10?06) with migraine after controlling for multiple testing (p < 0.05/11) (?gure 1a and appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10.5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     when we extended this analysis to migraine subtypes genetically determined elevated fviii activity (1.13 [1.05 1.22]/sd of fviii p = 1.74 × 10?03) vwf level (1.12 [1.05 1.20]/sd of vwf p = 7.98 × 10?04) and phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a level (1.22 [1.01 1.48]/sd of phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a p = 0.04) showed slightly stronger e?ects with ma than with overall migraine in spite of considerably smaller sample size in the migraine subtype gwas (?gure 1b and appendix; data available from dryad at doi. org/10.5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     although genetically determined decreased ?brinogen level was only nominally signi?cant for overall migraine it was signi?cantly related to ma (0.76 [0.64 0.91]/unit of natural log transformed ?brinogen p = 2.32 × 10?03) after controlling for multiple testing (?gure 1b and appendix; data available from dryad).;     among the hemostasis clinical tests aptt (0.93 [0.87 1.00]/second p = 0.02) was nominally signi?cantly linked with ma (?gure 1b and appendix; data available from dryad).;     none of the traits was linked with mo (?gure 1c and appendix; data available from dryad).;     reverse mr results showed no signi?cant e?ects of migraine or mo on any of the hemostatic factors (all p > 0.05 ?gure 2 and appendix; data available from dryad at doi. org/10.5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     sensitivity analysis results for a series of mr sensitivity analyses including mrpresso ivw weighted median simple median and mr-egger (appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10.5061/dryad. zkh18938p) were consistent with results from gsmr.;     after removing instruments proximal to the abo gene the association of genetically determined elevated fviii activity (1.05/sd of fviii p = 6.48 × 10?03) vwf level (1.05/sd of vwf p = 8.10 × 10?04) and phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a level (1.13/sd of phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a p = 5.44 × 10?06) with migraine remained the same (appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10.5061/dryad.zkh18938p).;     however when we further excluded instruments within 200 kb around the abo gene the e?ect of genetically determined elevated fviii activity with 20 instruments retained was attenuated and nonsigni?cant (or 1.02 p = 0.45) while the e?ects of genetically determined vwf level with 43 instruments and phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a level with 1 instrument remained similar (appendix; data available from dryad).;     results were again similar when we excluded all instruments on chromosome 9 (appendix; data available from dryad).;     for migraine subtypes we observed similar patterns e2484  neurology | volume 96 number 20 | may 18 2021  with overall migraine except the e?ects of ?brinogen level on ma were not a?ected (appendix; data available from dryad).;     the robust e?ects with vwf phosphorylated ?brinopeptide a and ?brinogen were further supported by leave-one-out sensitivity analysis that yielded instrumental e?ects with migraine and its subtypes similar to those in the primary analysis (appendix; data available from dryad).;     a ?nal mr sensitivity analysis including only cis-variants available for 5 of the protein measures (?brinogen fvii fxi vwf and pai-1) showed similar patterns and magnitudes of association as the primary mr results with ?brinogen and vwf being marginally signi?cant (p = 0.06 appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10.5061/ dryad.zkh18938p).;     multivariable mr results for fviii and vwf twenty-four instruments were shared (same instruments or instruments in high linkage disequilibrium) by fviii and vwf while 7 and 31 instruments were unique for fviii and vwf respectively (appendix; data available from dryad at doi.org/10. 5061/dryad.zkh18938p).

open_data_statements: besides the partial thra1 monomeric structure in complex with t3 (pdb id: 4lnw [34]) and t4 (pdb id: 4lnx [34]) diverse thrb ligand-binding domain structures were also available in complex with thyroid hormone as homodimer (pdb id: 3d57 [35]) as homodimer with thyroid hormone mimetics (pdb id: 1n46 [36]) or as dbd complexed with dna (pdb id: 3m9e [37]).;     in addition a thrb structure with a bound cofactor peptide (pdb id: 1bsx [38]) and in a heteromeric constellation with rxr (pdb id: 4zo1 [39]) were also available and provided structural information of potential protein interfaces and intermolecular interactions.;     it is accessible there under the following url: https: //www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clinvar/variation/992628/.
